Welcome to flopter’s documentation!¶

The IVAnalyser Class¶

class classes.base.IVAnalyser[source]¶

Abstract base class for the analysis of Langmuir Probe data.

Implementations of the IVAnalyser¶

class splopter.Splopter(data_mount_dir, group_name, folder_name, run_name=None, prepare=False)[source]¶

Implementation of IVAnalyser for the analysis of probe data from SPICE

prepare(homogenise=True, make_denormaliser=True)[source]¶

Check existence of, and then populate, the main flopter objects: inputparser, denormaliser and homogeniser.

Default behaviour is to populate all, mandatory behaviour is only to create input parser. Homogeniser and Denormaliser creation is controlled through the boolean input flags. Note that specifying the make_denormaliser flag does not automatically denormalise all data, it merely populates the denormaliser object.

Classes for Dealing with IV Data¶

class classes.ivdata.IVData(voltage, total_current, time, e_current=None, i_current=None, sigma=None, estimate_error_fl=True, sat_region=-30, std_err_scaler=1.0, trim_beg=0.0, trim_end=1.0)[source]¶
A dictionary which holds IV specific data, namely
  • Voltage
  • Current
  • Time
  • [Electron Current] (for simulations)
  • [Ion Current] (for simulations)
copy()[source]¶

Deep copy of IVData object, including conditional copying for electron and ion current, set trim values, sigma values and the estimation of error flag.

Returns:Deep copy of IVData object
static fractional_trim(iv_data, trim_beg=0.0, trim_end=1.0)[source]¶

Static method for trimming all the arrays in an IVData object from and to indices calculated from the fraction (0.0-1.0) of the arrays total length. e.g. trim_beg=0.2 would have a trim start at the nearest index to 20% through the array.

Parameters:
  • iv_data – IVData object to trim
  • trim_beg – Lower fraction of trim, default is the start of the array.
  • trim_end – Upper fraction of trim, default is the end of the array
Returns:

Trimmed IVData object
multi_fit(sat_region=-30, fitter=None, fix_vf_fl=False, plot_fl=False, print_fl=False)[source]¶

Multi-stage fitting method using an initial straight line fit to the saturation region of the IV curve (decided by the sat_region kwarg). The fitted I_sat is then left fixed while T_e and a are found with a 2 parameter fit, which gives the guess parameters for an unconstrained full IV fit.

Parameters:
  • sat_region – (Integer) Threshold voltage value below which the ‘Straight section’ is defined. The straight section is fitted to get an initial value of saturation current for subsequent fits.
  • fitter – Fitter object to be used for the fixed-I_sat fit and the final, full-free fit.
  • plot_fl – (Boolean) If true, plots the output of all 3 stages of fitting. Default is False.
  • fix_vf_fl – (Boolean) If true, fixes the floating potential for all 3 stages of fitting. The value used is the interpolated value of Voltage where Current = 0. Default is False.
  • print_fl – (Boolean) If true, prints fitter information to console.
Returns:

(IVFitData) Full 4-param IVFit data
static non_contiguous_trim(iv_data, selection)[source]¶

Static method for trimming a non-contiguous section of the IVData arrays. Non-contiguous area is trimmed using an array of indices, usually found with numpy’s where() function.

Parameters:
  • iv_data – IVData object to be trimmed
  • selection – List of indices referring to non-contiguous area to be trimmed.
Returns:

trimmed IVData object with all arrays of length (len(selection))
static positional_trim(iv_data, start, stop)[source]¶

Function for trimming an IVData’s underlying numpy arrays, using start and stop indices.

Parameters:
  • iv_data – IVData object to trim
  • start – Start trimming from this index - must be integer
  • stop – Stop index - must be integer
Returns:

trimmed IVData object with arrays of length (stop - start)
save(filename, columns=('t', 'V', 'I', 'sigma'))[source]¶

Converts the IV data object to a pandas dataframe and then stores is at the location specified by filename in csv format. The columns which are saved to file can be altered with the columns kwarg.

Parameters:
  • filename – String (or Path-like) to destination file.
  • columns – Which columns from the IVData object to store to file in the form of a tuple of strings. Default is (c.TIME, c.POTENTIAL, c.CURRENT, c.SIGMA)
split()[source]¶

Returns the potential, current (and optionally ion current) arrays from the IVData object

Returns:Tuple of [potential, current, ion_current (if present)]
class classes.fitdata.FitParam(value, error)[source]¶

Fit parameter object containing a value and its associated error, for use in storing fit parameters used in fitting.

Can be retrieved separately or as a pair.

class classes.fitdata.FitParamList(values, errors)[source]¶

Overridden list object for storing FitParam objects. Maintains functionality for retrieving separated lists simply.

Fitting¶

class fitters.ExponentialFitter[source]¶
class fitters.FullIVFitter[source]¶

IV Fitter implementation utilising the full, 4 parameter IV Curve fitting method.

class fitters.GaussianFitter(si_units=False, mu=1836.1526759556054, v_scale=1)[source]¶
fit(x_data, y_data, initial_vals=None, bounds=None, temp=None, sigma=None)[source]¶

Override of the fit method with included provision for automatic finding of the flow velocity if one is not specified. A separate temperature can be specified with the temp keyword. :param x_data: x-data for fit :param y_data: y-data for fit :param initial_vals: [optional] initial values to be fed to the fitting algorithm. If left None, v_0 will be

populated automatically using _get_v0_guess() and Temperature will be taken as a kwarg or taken from the default values.
Parameters:
  • bounds – The bounds for the fitting algorithm. If none are specified then the default parameters are
  • temp – [optional] temperature to use as an initial value for the fitting algorithm if v_0 is to be estimated automatically. Ignored if initial_vals is not None.
Return fitdata:

fitdata from fit, scaled back to normal values.

  • T_e in eV
  • V_0 in m/s
  • Electron mass used

  • V_0 in m/s
  • Ion mass used
class fitters.GenericFitter[source]¶

Semi-abstract base class for a Fitter object, which describes a model for fitting an IV curve.

Param:fixed_values
class fitters.GenericGaussianFitter(fwhm_fl=False)[source]¶

More generic gaussian function fitter. Variables are the amplitude (A), width (s - optionally able to be defined as the fwhm) and mean (x_0). Function is of the form:

( 1 ( x - x_0 )^2 )
f(x) = A * exp( - (———) )
( 2 ( s ) )

class fitters.NormalisedGaussianFitter(fwhm_fl=False)[source]¶

Normalised gaussian function fitter class. Implements a generic gaussian function with normalised area, i.e. the amplitude is controlled solely by the standard deviation.

class fitters.ScalableGaussianFitter(mu=1836.1526759556054, si_units=False, v_scale=1)[source]¶

class fitters.TriangleWaveFitter(frequency=None)[source]¶
fit(x_data, y_data, freq=None, initial_vals=None, bounds=None, sigma=None, calc_guess_fl=True)[source]¶

Override of the fit method with included provision for automatic finding of the amplitude and period of the triangular wave if one is not specified. :param x_data: x-data for fit :param y_data: y-data for fit :param freq: specify a known frequency of the wave, will be automatically found if not :param initial_vals: [optional] initial values to be fed to the fitting algorithm. If left None, by

default amplitude and period will be populated automatically using get_initial_guess(). This behaviour can be turned off with the calc_guess_fl param.
Parameters:
  • bounds – [optional] The bounds for the fitting algorithm. If none are specified then the default parameters are used.
  • calc_guess_fl – [optional] Boolean flag to turn on or off the calculation of an initial guess if one is not given.
Return fitdata:

fitdata from fit.

Integration with SPICE¶

class normalisation.Converter[source]¶

Base class for a converter object, which normalises or denormalises an input variable.

Principle method of conversion is to call the converter object itself with the desired conversion_type as a parameter. Subclasses need to override the given conversion functions defined below

class normalisation.Denormaliser(dt=1.0, dimensions=2, input_parser=None, input_filename=None, edge_ratio=1, temperature=None)[source]¶

Class for de-normalising values given by SPICE simulations.

Stores an input parser object containing the used input file and then builds conversion values from this.

class normalisation.Normaliser[source]¶

Class for normalising values for use in SPICE simulations.

class homogenisation.Homogeniser(source, data_filename=None, data=None)[source]¶

Abstract base class for the Homogeniser object.

Takes data from some source and homogenises it for analysis within flopter. This class should be inherited from, and the homogenise and read_data methods overridden, in order to make an additional data source for flopter.

Can separately be created and fed data using the set_data() method.

homogenise()[source]¶

Abstract method for homogenising the data stored in Homogeniser.data :return:

  • An IV_Data object.
  • Raw data, preferably in a dictionary.
read_data()[source]¶

Abstract method for reading data from Homogeniser.filename into the Homogeniser.data container. Note that data can be set directly with its setter ‘set_data()’.

Should not return anything, but instead populate the internal class variable Homogeniser.data

class homogenisation.Spice2Homogeniser(input_parser=None, input_filename=None, **kwargs)[source]¶
homogenise()[source]¶

Homogenise function for creaiton of IVData objects for use in SPICE simulation analysis. Uses specified inputfile or inputparser to get relevant simulation timing data and then slices up the current and voltage traces accordingly. Also uses InputParser methods to evaluate probe collection objects. :param data: :return:

read_data()[source]¶

Abstract method for reading data from Homogeniser.filename into the Homogeniser.data container. Note that data can be set directly with its setter ‘set_data()’.

Should not return anything, but instead populate the internal class variable Homogeniser.data

class inputparser.InputParser(*args, comment_prefixes=('!', '$end'), expected_dupes=('rectangle', 'triangle', 'circle', 'diag_reg', 'specie'), input_filename=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Subclass of ConfigParser, edited to parse SPICE input files which are sectioned by dollar signed headings.

Also changes the default comment_prefixes to:
  • the exclamation mark (!) used in Spice input files
  • the ‘$end’ marker used by Spice to denote the end of a section.

Supports reading in the commented parameters at the end of SPICE2 input files. Can also read in a file upon initialisation, with the optional kwarg ‘input_filename’

Functions the same way as a config parser in all other ways.

get_commented_params()[source]¶

Returns commented parameters if they have been read into the object, throws exception if not.

Returns:Dictionary containing commented parameters
get_diag_index(diag_name)[source]¶

Find index of diagnostic within an input file

get_hist_diag_regions(species=2)[source]¶

Find the simulation coordinates of each diagnostic which is a histogram and return them as a dictionary of lists.

Returns:[list] Dictionary of lists containing the coordinates of the diagnostic region. In the format {diag_name: [z_low, z_high, y_low, y_high], … }
get_hist_index(hist_name)[source]¶

Find the index of a diagnostic which is a histogram within an input file

get_probe_obj_indices()[source]¶

Returns the index (or indices if the probe is a compound shape) of the object within the simulation which is acting as a probe i.e. has ‘param1’ set to 3. The indices can be used to reference the correct array in objectscurrent, for example.

Returns:[int] Indices of probes in simulation object array, returned as a list.
get_scaling_values(len_diag, len_builtin)[source]¶

Calculates the scaling values (n’ and r) which are needed to extend the diagnostic outputs to the right length and downsample them for homogenisation of SPICE IV sweeps

Parameters:
  • len_diag – length of raw diagnostic output array (n)
  • len_builtin – length of builtin output array (M)
Return n_leading:
 

size of array to prepend onto the diagnostic array
Return ratio:

ratio of extended diagnostic output array to builtin output array (e.g. objectscurrent):
get_wall_obj_indices()[source]¶

Returns the index (or indices if using a compound shape) of the object within the simulation which is acting set to have a floating potential i.e. has ‘param1’ set to 2. The indices can be used to reference the correct array in objectscurrent, for example.

Returns:[int] Indices of floating potential walls in simulation object array, returned as a list.
has_commented_params()[source]¶

Method to check if parser has read in commented parameters by checking if the ‘commented params’ section exists :return: Boolean stating if parameters have been read successfully

read_commented_params(comments)[source]¶

Reads out the paramters from the end of a SPICE2 input file if they are embedded within comments.

Parameters:comments – List of strings containing the commented parameters (in form ‘! T_e = 5.2e2 eV’)
Returns:Dictionary containing commented parameters
read_file(f, source=None, read_comments=False)[source]¶

Like read() but the argument must be a file-like object.

The `f’ argument must be iterable, returning one line at a time. Optional second argument is the `source’ specifying the name of the file being read. If not given, it is taken from f.name. If `f’ has no `name’ attribute, `<???>’ is used.
